news_summary: Innovative discoveries and efforts are advancing sustainable energy, resilient food systems, environmental awareness, and climate justice worldwide.
news_summary_fr: Les découvertes et les efforts novateurs font progresser l'énergie durable, les systèmes alimentaires résilients, la sensibilisation à l'environnement et la justice climatique dans le monde entier.
news_summary_es: Los descubrimientos y esfuerzos innovadores hacen avanzar la energía sostenible, los sistemas alimentarios resistentes, la concienciación medioambiental y la justicia climática en todo el mundo.

articles.title: The real-life Kryptonite found in Serbia—and why it could power the future
articles.summary: Deep in Serbia's Jadar Valley, scientists discovered a mineral with an uncanny resemblance to Superman's Kryptonite both in composition and name. Dubbed jadarite, this dull white crystal lacks the glowing green menace of its comic book counterpart but packs a punch in the real world. Rich in lithium and boron, jadarite could help supercharge the global transition to green energy.
articles.content:
Key points

Jadarite has been likened to Superman's 'kryptonite' based on their similar chemical compositions.

It was discovered in the Jadar Valley of Serbia and officially recognized as a new mineral in 2006.

Whilst lacking any actual superpowers, jadarite has great potential as an important resource of lithium and boron.

Kryptonite's twin on Earth

Described as 'Earth's kryptonite twin', jadarite is a rare and fascinating mineral that quickly caught the attention of scientists and Superman fans alike.

The mineral was discovered by exploration geologists from Rio Tinto in 2004 in the Jadar Valley of Serbia. Its chemical composition is exactly like the fictional kryptonite right out of the comic books -- with a few differences. Where kryptonite glows green and weakens superheroes, jadarite offers immense potential for Earth's energy transition away from fossil fuels.

A new mineral on the scene

Jadarite was identified by Rio Tinto geologists during exploration drilling and didn't match any known mineral at the time. After analysis by the Natural History Museum in London and the National Research Council of Canada, it was officially recognised as a new mineral in 2006.

Jadarite is a "sodium lithium boron silicate hydroxide" mineral, coincidentally the same scientific name written on a case containing kryptonite stolen by Lex Luther from a museum in the film Superman Returns.

While the film version of kryptonite contains fluorine and glows an eery green, the chemical formula of the real version is LiNaSiB₃O₇(OH) and is a much less supernatural dull white -- though it does fluoresce a pinkish-orange under UV light.

Super in its own right

Michael Page, a scientist with Australia's Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), said that the mineral is 'super' in its own right.

"While lacking any supernatural powers the real jadarite has great potential as an important source of lithium and boron," Michael said.

"In fact, the Jadar deposit where it was first discovered is considered one of the largest lithium deposits in the world, making it a potential game-changer for the global green energy transition."

ANSTO is one of the three supporting agencies of the Australian Critical Minerals R&D Hub, alongside Geoscience Australia and CSIRO, hosted by CSIRO. One of the Hub's key missions is to better connect Australia's R&D ecosystem, including Australian industry, to enable access and utilization of critical minerals to strengthen Australia's value chain domestically and across the globe.

The work that ANSTO does has a significant focus on how these critical minerals, such as jadarite, can be utilised to support Australian industry in a commercial capacity.

"At ANSTO, we work with industry to develop process solutions for many critical elements including lithium, and the challenges posed by a new type of mineral resource are very exciting," Michael said.

ANSTO has produced battery grade lithium chemicals from many different mineral deposits, such as spodumene, lepidolite and even jadarite, ensuring that Australian miners receive the support they need to meet the challenges of the energy transition.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of jadarite, a mineral rich in lithium and boron, has strong potential to support the global transition to green energy, representing a significant environmental and technological breakthrough that could reduce reliance on fossil fuels and promote sustainability.
articles.personality_title: Serbia's real-life kryptonite: a mineral that could power our green future
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Deep in Serbia's Jadar Valley, scientists found a unique mineral named jadarite. It caught attention because it looks a bit like Superman’s kryptonite and shares some chemical traits with it. But unlike the glowing green rock from comics, jadarite is a dull white crystal.

**What happened**
Discovered in 2006, jadarite is special because it contains lithium and boron—two elements that are key for modern green technologies. Lithium, for example, is a vital part of batteries in electric cars and renewable energy storage. Boron helps in making strong, lightweight materials and improving energy efficiency.

**Impact**
This discovery means jadarite could become an important resource to help shift the world away from fossil fuels. By supplying lithium and boron, it supports the development of cleaner energy solutions, which is great news for fighting climate change and promoting sustainability.

**What's next step**
Researchers and companies will focus on responsibly mining and processing jadarite to unlock its full potential. The goal is to integrate it into green technology supply chains, helping reduce environmental damage and meet growing energy demands sustainably.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Jadarite, Serbia’s real-life kryptonite, holds promise as a powerful natural resource to fuel a cleaner, greener future.
articles.personality_title_fr: La kryptonite réelle de Serbie : un minéral qui pourrait alimenter notre avenir écologique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Au cœur de la vallée de Jadar en Serbie, des scientifiques ont découvert un minéral unique appelé jadarite. Il a attiré l’attention car il ressemble un peu à la kryptonite de Superman et partage certaines caractéristiques chimiques avec celle-ci. Mais contrairement à la roche verte brillante des bandes dessinées, la jadarite est un cristal blanc terne.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Découverte en 2006, la jadarite est spéciale car elle contient du lithium et du bore, deux éléments essentiels pour les technologies vertes modernes. Par exemple, le lithium est un composant vital des batteries pour voitures électriques et le stockage d’énergie renouvelable. Le bore aide à fabriquer des matériaux légers et solides et améliore l’efficacité énergétique.

**Impact**
Cette découverte signifie que la jadarite pourrait devenir une ressource importante pour aider la transition mondiale loin des énergies fossiles. En fournissant du lithium et du bore, elle soutient le développement de solutions énergétiques plus propres, une excellente nouvelle pour lutter contre le changement climatique et promouvoir la durabilité.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs et les entreprises vont se concentrer sur l'extraction et le traitement responsables de la jadarite pour exploiter tout son potentiel. L’objectif est de l’intégrer dans les chaînes d’approvisionnement des technologies vertes, afin de réduire les dégâts environnementaux et répondre durablement à la demande énergétique croissante.

**Une phrase à retenir**
La jadarite, la kryptonite réelle de Serbie, promet d’être une ressource naturelle puissante pour alimenter un avenir plus propre et plus vert.
articles.personality_title_es: La kryptonita real de Serbia: un mineral que podría impulsar nuestro futuro verde
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En el valle de Jadar en Serbia, los científicos encontraron un mineral único llamado jadarita. Llamó la atención porque se parece un poco a la kryptonita de Superman y comparte algunas características químicas con ella. Pero a diferencia de la roca verde brillante de los cómics, la jadarita es un cristal blanco opaco.

**Qué pasó**
Descubierta en 2006, la jadarita es especial porque contiene litio y boro, dos elementos clave para las tecnologías verdes modernas. Por ejemplo, el litio es vital para las baterías de autos eléctricos y el almacenamiento de energía renovable. El boro ayuda a fabricar materiales livianos y resistentes, mejorando la eficiencia energética.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento significa que la jadarita podría convertirse en un recurso importante para ayudar a la transición mundial lejos de los combustibles fósiles. Al aportar litio y boro, apoya el desarrollo de soluciones energéticas más limpias, una gran noticia para combatir el cambio climático y promover la sostenibilidad.

**Próximo paso**
Investigadores y empresas se enfocarán en extraer y procesar la jadarita de manera responsable para aprovechar todo su potencial. El objetivo es integrarla en las cadenas de suministro de tecnologías verdes, ayudando a reducir el daño ambiental y a satisfacer la creciente demanda energética de forma sostenible.

**Una frase para llevar**
La jadarita, la kryptonita real de Serbia, promete ser un recurso natural poderoso para impulsar un futuro más limpio y verde.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a glowing pale white mineral crystal cluster nestled in the serene landscapes of Serbia’s Jadar Valley at dawn, softly illuminated by gentle pinkish-orange light under a subtle ultraviolet glow, with stylized abstract energy waves radiating from the mineral symbolizing clean, green future power and transformation.

articles.title: How I’m helping to develop more-resilient food systems
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02352-wGeographer Bhogtoram Mawroh works with Indigenous People in Meghalaya, India, to adapt agriculture to climate change.
articles.content:
“Here in Meghalaya, India, the practices of Indigenous Peoples influence the foods that we eat and where they come from. It’s a food system characterized by richness and diversity. The Khasi, Garo and Karbi Indigenous People here grow multiple plant species together on the same land, use several approaches to farming and rely on knowledge of the surrounding forests and rivers. In the conventional system of farming, people grow food in one place all the time. But here, people farm in different areas across the mountains every year.

These food systems are resilient because of that diversity. Climate change is affecting agricultural systems around the world and farming contributes to around 30% of global greenhouse-gas emissions. Implementing Indigenous Peoples’ food systems is among the game-changing solutions that can help us to adapt.

In this photo, I’m examining bean leaves with Khasi farmer Ricona as part of my research on the links between Indigenous Peoples’ food systems, food sovereignty, nutrition and natural-resource management, as a consultant for the North East Society for Agroecology Support in Shillong, India. Over the past few years in Meghalaya, we’ve experienced record rainfall, rising temperatures and extreme heat waves.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights efforts by a geographer working with Indigenous communities to adapt agriculture to climate change, which represents environmental progress and community cooperation to build resilience against climate challenges.
articles.personality_title: Building stronger food systems with Indigenous wisdom in Meghalaya
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In Meghalaya, India, Indigenous Peoples like the Khasi, Garo, and Karbi have long practiced farming in ways that work closely with nature. Their traditional methods include growing many types of plants together and using knowledge of local forests and rivers to guide farming.

**What happened**
Geographer Bhogtoram Mawroh is partnering with these Indigenous communities to adapt their farming practices to the challenges of climate change. Instead of farming one crop in the same place all the time, they use diverse methods that help the land and crops stay healthy even as weather patterns shift.

**Impact**
This approach strengthens local food systems by making them more resilient against climate risks. It helps protect biodiversity, ensures steady food availability, and supports the cultural heritage of Indigenous Peoples. These combined efforts show how traditional knowledge and modern science can work hand in hand.

**What's next step**
The next goal is to expand these climate-smart farming techniques to other parts of India and the world. Sharing what works can inspire more communities to protect their food supplies while caring for the environment.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By blending Indigenous wisdom with climate adaptation, Meghalaya is growing stronger, more diverse food systems that feed both people and the planet.
articles.personality_title_fr: Renforcer les systèmes alimentaires grâce à la sagesse indigène au Meghalaya
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Au Meghalaya, en Inde, les peuples indigènes tels que les Khasi, Garo et Karbi pratiquent depuis longtemps une agriculture en harmonie avec la nature. Leurs méthodes traditionnelles incluent la culture de plusieurs plantes ensemble et l’utilisation des connaissances des forêts et rivières locales pour guider l’agriculture.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Le géographe Bhogtoram Mawroh collabore avec ces communautés indigènes pour adapter leurs pratiques agricoles aux défis du changement climatique. Au lieu de cultiver une seule plante toujours au même endroit, ils utilisent des méthodes diversifiées qui aident la terre et les cultures à rester en bonne santé malgré les changements climatiques.

**Impact**
Cette approche renforce les systèmes alimentaires locaux en les rendant plus résistants aux risques climatiques. Elle protège la biodiversité, assure une alimentation constante et soutient le patrimoine culturel des peuples indigènes. Ces efforts montrent comment savoir traditionnel et science moderne peuvent travailler ensemble.

**Prochaine étape**
L’objectif suivant est d’étendre ces techniques agricoles adaptées au climat dans d’autres régions de l’Inde et du monde. Partager ces réussites peut encourager davantage de communautés à protéger leur alimentation tout en prenant soin de l’environnement.

**Un conseil à retenir**
En alliant sagesse indigène et adaptation climatique, le Meghalaya développe des systèmes alimentaires plus solides et diversifiés qui nourrissent à la fois les populations et la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Fortaleciendo sistemas alimentarios con la sabiduría indígena en Meghalaya
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En Meghalaya, India, los pueblos indígenas como Khasi, Garo y Karbi han practicado durante mucho tiempo una agricultura que trabaja en estrecha armonía con la naturaleza. Sus métodos tradicionales incluyen cultivar varios tipos de plantas juntas y usar el conocimiento de los bosques y ríos locales para guiar la agricultura.

**Qué pasó**
El geógrafo Bhogtoram Mawroh trabaja junto a estas comunidades indígenas para adaptar sus prácticas agrícolas a los desafíos del cambio climático. En lugar de cultivar un solo alimento siempre en el mismo lugar, usan métodos diversos que ayudan a mantener saludables la tierra y los cultivos incluso con cambios en el clima.

**Impacto**
Este enfoque fortalece los sistemas alimentarios locales haciéndolos más resistentes a los riesgos climáticos. Protege la biodiversidad, asegura el suministro constante de alimentos y apoya el patrimonio cultural de los pueblos indígenas. Estos esfuerzos demuestran cómo el conocimiento tradicional y la ciencia moderna pueden trabajar juntos.

**Próximo paso**
La siguiente meta es expandir estas técnicas agrícolas adaptadas al clima a otras partes de India y el mundo. Compartir lo que funciona puede inspirar a más comunidades a proteger sus alimentos y cuidar el medio ambiente.

**Una frase clave**
Mezclando la sabiduría indígena con la adaptación climática, Meghalaya está creando sistemas alimentarios más fuertes y diversos que alimentan a las personas y al planeta.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a lush, terraced mountain landscape in Meghalaya with diverse crops like beans and multiple plants growing together, alongside symbolic silhouettes of Khasi and Garo farming tools gently resting near flowing forest rivers, using soft, natural earth tones and greens to evoke resilience and harmony in Indigenous food systems.

articles.title: Best of Earth911 Podcast: Josh Dorfman Makes Environmentalism Supercool
articles.summary:
Josh Dorfman—known for his The Lazy Environmentalist TV and book series—visites to share his latest...
The post Best of Earth911 Podcast: Josh Dorfman Makes Environmentalism Supercool appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Josh Dorfman—known for his The Lazy Environmentalist TV and book series—visites to share his latest efforts to make sustainability seamless, smart, and scalable. From hosting eco-living shows to launching climate tech ventures, Dorfman’s mission: make sustainable choices attractive and accessible. In the 1990s, while working in China, Dorfman saw the country’s shift from bicycles to cars and realized the environmental cost of global development. That insight set him on a path to shift consumer culture toward greener living. “People don’t respond to guilt,” he said. “They respond to practical, self-interested solutions that make their lives better.” Dorfman now leads two new initiatives: Plantd and Supercool. By blending smart storytelling with practical solutions, Dorfman shows how sustainability can be not just necessary—but undeniably cool.

Plantd is a carbon-negative building materials startup using ultra-fast-growing grass to produce high-performance panels that outperform and underprice traditional plywood. Backed by former SpaceX engineers, Plantd’s electric, zero-smokestack production line locks atmospheric carbon into walls, floors, and roofs—without cutting down trees. Their work has caught serious attention: DR Horton, the largest U.S. homebuilder, recently placed an order for 10 million panels. The Supercool podcast and newsletter spotlight climate innovation that resonates across political lines. Dorfman’s storytelling targets the middle ground—where sustainability aligns with health, economics, and lifestyle. Episodes feature stories like upcycled e-bike marketplaces, AI-optimized HVAC systems, and green retrofits of federal buildings. “We already have the technology to solve climate change,” Dorfman said. “What we need is faster adoption—and that comes from telling the right stories.” You can learn more about Plantd’s carbon-negative building materials at https://www.plantdmaterials.com/ and tune into the Supercool podcast at https://getsuper.cool/

Subscribe to Sustainability In Your Ear on iTunes

Follow Sustainability In Your Ear on Spreaker, iHeartRadio, or YouTube

Editor’s Note: This episode originally aired on April 7, 2025.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Josh Dorfman's efforts to make environmentalism appealing and accessible, which promotes environmental progress and awareness. This is likely to inspire and motivate people to engage in positive environmental actions.
articles.personality_title: Josh Dorfman makes environmentalism supercool and easy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Josh Dorfman, known for his TV show and book series The Lazy Environmentalist, has spent years working to make sustainable living something everyone can enjoy and easily adopt. His journey started in the 1990s when he saw the environmental impact of rapid development in China, inspiring him to find better ways to help people live greener lives.

**What happened**
Josh recently shared his latest work on the Earth911 podcast, where he talked about making sustainability seamless, smart, and scalable. He combines entertaining TV shows with launching climate technology projects to make eco-friendly choices more appealing and easier for people to include in their daily routines.

**Impact**
By making environmentalism supercool and accessible, Josh is encouraging more people to take positive action for the planet. His approach helps break down the idea that sustainable living is difficult or boring, inspiring real change and awareness in communities.

**What's next step**
Josh plans to continue expanding his reach through media and innovative tech solutions, aiming to help even more people make smarter, greener choices effortlessly. His future projects will focus on making sustainability practical and attractive on a larger scale.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Josh Dorfman’s creative work is turning environmentalism into a fun, easy lifestyle choice that anyone can embrace to help the planet.
articles.personality_title_fr: Josh Dorfman rend l’écologie super cool et facile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Josh Dorfman, connu pour son émission télé et sa série de livres The Lazy Environmentalist, travaille depuis des années à rendre le mode de vie durable accessible et agréable pour tous. Son parcours a commencé dans les années 1990, lorsqu’il a vu l’impact environnemental du développement rapide en Chine, ce qui l’a inspiré à trouver de meilleures façons d’aider les gens à vivre plus écologiquement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Josh a récemment partagé son dernier travail dans le podcast Earth911, où il a parlé de rendre la durabilité simple, intelligente et à grande échelle. Il combine des émissions divertissantes avec le lancement de projets technologiques liés au climat pour rendre les choix écologiques plus attrayants et faciles à intégrer au quotidien.

**Impact**
En rendant l’écologie super cool et accessible, Josh encourage plus de personnes à agir positivement pour la planète. Son approche démystifie l’idée que vivre durablement est compliqué ou ennuyeux, inspirant de vrais changements et une meilleure conscience dans les communautés.

**Prochaine étape**
Josh prévoit de continuer à élargir son audience via les médias et des solutions technologiques innovantes, visant à aider encore plus de personnes à faire des choix plus verts et plus intelligents sans effort. Ses futurs projets viseront à rendre la durabilité pratique et attrayante à grande échelle.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Le travail créatif de Josh Dorfman transforme l’écologie en un style de vie amusant et facile que tout le monde peut adopter pour aider la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Josh Dorfman hace que el ambientalismo sea genial y fácil
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Josh Dorfman, conocido por su programa de televisión y la serie de libros The Lazy Environmentalist, ha dedicado años a hacer que vivir de forma sostenible sea accesible y agradable para todos. Su camino comenzó en los años 90, cuando vio el impacto ambiental del rápido desarrollo en China, lo que lo inspiró a encontrar mejores maneras de ayudar a las personas a vivir de forma más ecológica.

**Qué pasó**
Josh compartió recientemente su último trabajo en el podcast Earth911, donde habló de hacer que la sostenibilidad sea sencilla, inteligente y escalable. Combina programas entretenidos con el lanzamiento de proyectos tecnológicos climáticos para que las opciones ecológicas sean más atractivas y fáciles de incorporar en la vida diaria.

**Impacto**
Al hacer que el ambientalismo sea genial y accesible, Josh está animando a más personas a tomar acciones positivas por el planeta. Su enfoque ayuda a romper la idea de que vivir de manera sostenible es difícil o aburrido, inspirando cambios reales y conciencia en las comunidades.

**Próximo paso**
Josh planea seguir ampliando su alcance a través de medios y soluciones tecnológicas innovadoras, con la meta de ayudar a aún más personas a hacer elecciones más verdes e inteligentes sin esfuerzo. Sus futuros proyectos se centrarán en hacer que la sostenibilidad sea práctica y atractiva a gran escala.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El trabajo creativo de Josh Dorfman está convirtiendo el ambientalismo en una forma de vida divertida y fácil que cualquiera puede adoptar para ayudar al planeta.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a lush, green building made from vibrant panels resembling fast-growing grass, with subtle carbon molecules gently entwined in the structure, set against a soft sky; nearby, a sleek, glowing microphone and vintage radio waves ripple outward, symbolizing storytelling that bridges communities through eco-friendly innovation.

articles.title: How the world’s highest court bolstered the fight for climate reparations
articles.content:
As global inaction over the climate crisis has mounted and Pacific islands nations have watched in frustration as their calls for decisive action have gone unheeded, a growing number of them, led by Vanuatu, have turned to the courts. If policymakers won’t act, they hoped, perhaps the courts would.

And so island nations in the South Pacific region of Melanesia, where Indigenous communities have had to flee their traditional lands due to landslides and rising seas, filed a case that was ultimately joined by more than 130 countries. Together, they urged the International Court of Justice to decide whether nation-states have a legal obligation to address climate change, and whether those harmed by a warming world have a right to reparations.

Justices considered testimony in Indigenous Pacific languages, heard arguments from Indigenous attorneys, and learned how Indigenous traditions are being harmed by the typhoons, rising seas, and other extreme weather events worsened by the burning of fossil fuels.

Last week, the court issued a landmark ruling that climate harm violates international law. The seismic decision, although advisory, opens the door for countries like Vanuatu to seek reparations from some of the world’s biggest polluters, and it is widely expected to shape current — and future — climate lawsuits as early as this week.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

“What the court has done has come in and made it crystal clear that affected frontline nations and communities that have been devastated by climate harm — harm that can be traced to the conduct of specific countries and corporations — those communities, those nations, they absolutely have the right to redress and reparations,” said Joie Chowdhury, a senior attorney at the Center for International Environmental Law.

The court’s decision, handed down Wednesday, said that all nations have a legal obligation to limit greenhouse gas emissions and failing to do so, through the support of fossil fuel production, could violate international law. The justices didn’t disclose how much major polluters might owe, and said the level of reparations would be determined on a case-by-case basis. But Chowdhury said she expects the ruling to immediately influence ongoing climate litigation worldwide, and prompt new lawsuits. “There are litigators all over the world that are looking to this case and will absolutely bring it into the courtroom,” she said.

Kelly Matheson, deputy director of global strategy for Our Children’s Trust, a nonprofit law firm representing youth in climate litigation, said the organization is already incorporating the language of the advisory opinion into an amicus brief that it plans to file in a case in Latin America this fall. She also expects the ruling to feature heavily in La Rose v. His Majesty the King, a Canadian climate case youth plaintiffs brought against the Canadian government scheduled for trial next year, as well as a climate case pending before the African Court of Human and Peoples’ Rights.

Government attorneys also are studying the decision to determine whether their countries can sue. Malik Amin Aslam Khan, former minister of the environment in Pakistan, said the ruling “opens up a legally grounded pathway for claiming climate damages and demanding reparations for countries like Pakistan, which has continuously been one of the world’s worst climate sufferers and has credibly recorded climate damage costs crossing $40 billion in the past decade alone.”

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Ralph Regenvanu, Vanuatu’s minister of climate change, said Vanuatu plans to immediately push for a resolution at the United Nations General Assembly to implement the advisory opinion. The government also plans to use the ruling to advocate for better climate financing for the Pacific and better regional and domestic policies to address the climate crisis.

“For the first time in history, the ICJ has spoken directly about the biggest threat facing humanity, which is climate change,” Regenvanu said during a press conference at The Hague last week. ”It’s very important now, as the world goes forward, that we make sure our actions align with what was decided or what came out today from the court.”

The ruling builds upon a growing consensus in international law that states have a legal obligation to limit greenhouse gas emissions. Last year, the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea ruled that the 169 countries that have signed the U.N. Convention on the Law of the Sea — a list that includes China and India, but not the U.S. — must reduce emissions. It was another victory led by Pacific island nations as well as island nations in the Caribbean and West Indies.

“For the first time in history, the ICJ has spoken directly about the biggest threat facing humanity,” Ralph Regenvanu, Vanuatu’s climate change minister, said of the ruling. He is seen here in court before the decision was handed down. John Thys / AFP via Getty Images

Earlier this month, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, a regional court for Latin and South America, ruled that a healthy climate is a human right and governments should limit emissions. The court also said they should prevent harm to marginalized communities such as Indigenous peoples and emphasized their role in combating climate change.

“Indigenous peoples play an essential role in the preservation and sustainable management of these ecosystems because their ancestral knowledge and their close relationship with nature proved essential for the conservation of biodiversity and the mitigation of climate change,” the court wrote. “Therefore, states should listen to them and facilitate their continuing participation in decision-making.”

Matheson said that when Sheila Watt-Cloutier, an Indigenous Inuk woman who then chaired the Inuit Circumpolar Conference, brought a climate case to the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights wo decades ago, it dismissed her claims within two pages. Several years later, Palau brought a similar case before the ICJ to no avail.

“For the law to be moving at this speed — to go from dismissals and no consideration of the impact that climate change has on human rights 20 years ago, when the first case was filed, to now you have opinions from all but one of the highest courts in the world — is amazing,” she said, noting that an African court is expected to weigh in soon.

While the ICJ ruling did not expound on the rights of Indigenous peoples and focused on the responsibilities of nation-states, it did clarify a question that has long troubled leaders of countries like Tuvalu and Kiribati that are losing land to rising seas: What happens to their borders if their islands disappear? On that note, the ICJ said any recognized borders should remain unchanged, which is important to ensure they continue to have a political voice on the international stage and control over their waters. “That presumption of statehood and sovereignty is a critical bit,” said Johanna Gusman, a senior attorney for the Center for International Environmental Law.

The case was initiated six years ago by a group of law students in Vanuatu and led by the government of Vanuatu and the Melanesian Spearhead Group, which represents several nations in that region of the Pacific and the Indigenous people of New Caledonia.

“By affirming the science, the ICJ has mandated countries to urgently phase out fossil fuels because they are no longer tenable for small island state communities in the Pacific, and for young people and for future generations,” Vishal Prasad, director of Pacific Islands, Students Fighting Climate Change, said during a press conference at The Hague. “This opinion is a lifeline and an opportunity to protect all that we hold dear, and all that we love.”

The United Nations established the International Court of Justice in the wake of World War II to help the global community address conflicts and concerns peacefully and judicially. It has heard cases on issues ranging from nuclear testing to fishing rights to the status of entire territories, such as Western Sahara. While not binding, its decisions are significant because they interpret international law and clarify states’ legal responsibilities. In this case, the court reviewed several treaties, including the 2015 Paris Agreement climate accord, and concluded that under those treaties and under customary international law, all nations have a legal obligation to limit emissions and may owe compensation to countries that are harmed.

There are limits to who can bring cases before the ICJ, which only hears cases brought by nation-states and not, for example, Indigenous political entities such as First Nations in Canada. Gusman said that Indigenous peoples may instead use the language of the cases in domestic disputes or through other U.N. venues. For example, “Indigenous nations and First Nations within Canada now have stronger legal backbones to take cases against Canada,” she said.

The court’s ruling will also be dulled somewhat in the United States, which has long rejected the ICJ’s authority and under President Donald J. Trump has been retreating even further from climate action. The U.S. and China are two major polluters whose rejection of the ICJ’s jurisdiction could prevent a country like Vanuatu from suing them directly over their emissions.

Korey Silverman-Roati, a senior fellow at the Sabin Center for Climate Change Law, said the ruling is a seminal moment for climate litigation but that the effects in the U.S. will be muted because U.S. courts don’t traditionally recognize the ICJ’s authority. “I don’t think we can expect that the direct language of the ruling will impact cases in the U.S.,” he said. He thinks the advisory opinion will likely instead influence other countries whose judicial systems give more weight to the ICJ, and influence the U.S. through the ruling’s use in international negotiations.

Already, the ruling is expected to figure heavily at this year’s Conference of the Parties, or COP, in November in Brazil. Last year, negotiations fell apart in the waning minute to the disappointment of Pacific island nations and many climate advocates who criticized the amount of money pledged by U.N. member states as woefully insufficient.

“The advisory opinion will be an essential tool that we in the Global South will use at the next meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, the U.N.’s climate change and biodiversity conferences, and everywhere to advocate for climate justice,” said Ilan Kiloe, acting director general of the Melanesian Spearhead Group. He said Pacific peoples have already suffered forced relocations due to climate change. “We have already lost much of what defines us as Pacific Islanders.”

Tik Root contributed reporting to this story.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant legal victory by the world's highest court that supports the fight for climate reparations, which is a positive step toward environmental justice and accountability. This decision can inspire hope for stronger climate action and support for vulnerable communities affected by climate change.
articles.personality_title: World’s highest court backs climate reparations for Pacific island nations
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Small island nations in the Pacific have been losing their homes to rising seas and landslides caused by climate change. Despite their urgent pleas for help, global leaders have often failed to take strong action. Frustrated, these nations turned to the world’s highest court, hoping for justice and support.

**What happened**
Led by the island nation of Vanuatu, Pacific countries filed a legal case to demand climate reparations—financial help and responsibility from those who have contributed most to pollution and global warming. The court ruled in their favor, recognizing the harm these communities face and supporting their right to seek compensation.

**Impact**
This legal victory is a big step toward environmental justice. It sends a clear message that countries causing climate damage can be held accountable. It also brings hope to vulnerable communities that they are not alone and that their struggles are being heard on the world stage.

**What's next step**
With this court decision, these island nations can now push for real compensation and stronger climate action from major polluters. The ruling also sets a precedent that could encourage other vulnerable communities to seek justice and support.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The world’s highest court has empowered Pacific island nations to fight for climate reparations, marking a hopeful turn toward accountability and justice in the climate crisis.
articles.personality_title_fr: La plus haute cour mondiale soutient les réparations climatiques pour les îles du Pacifique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
De petites nations insulaires du Pacifique perdent leurs terres à cause de la montée des eaux et des glissements de terrain liés au changement climatique. Malgré leurs appels urgents à l’aide, les dirigeants mondiaux ont souvent manqué d’agir. Frustrées, ces nations se sont tournées vers la plus haute cour mondiale, espérant justice et soutien.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Menées par Vanuatu, des nations du Pacifique ont déposé une plainte juridique pour demander des réparations climatiques—une aide financière et la reconnaissance de la responsabilité des pays les plus pollueurs. La cour a statué en leur faveur, reconnaissant les dommages subis et leur droit à la compensation.

**Impact**
Cette victoire juridique est une avancée majeure vers la justice environnementale. Elle envoie un message clair: les pays responsables des dégâts climatiques peuvent être tenus pour responsables. Elle redonne aussi de l’espoir aux communautés vulnérables, montrant qu’elles sont entendues sur la scène mondiale.

**Prochaine étape**
Grâce à cette décision, ces nations insulaires peuvent maintenant demander une compensation réelle et une action climatique plus forte des gros pollueurs. Ce verdict ouvre aussi la voie à d’autres communautés vulnérables pour chercher justice et soutien.

**Résumé en une phrase**
La plus haute cour mondiale a donné aux îles du Pacifique le pouvoir de réclamer des réparations climatiques, marquant un tournant prometteur vers la responsabilité et la justice face à la crise climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: El tribunal más alto del mundo apoya reparaciones climáticas para las islas del Pacífico
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Pequeñas naciones insulares del Pacífico han perdido sus hogares debido al aumento del nivel del mar y deslizamientos causados por el cambio climático. A pesar de sus urgentes súplicas, los líderes mundiales a menudo no han actuado con firmeza. Frustradas, estas naciones acudieron al tribunal más alto del mundo, esperando justicia y apoyo.

**Qué pasó**
Dirigidas por Vanuatu, las naciones del Pacífico presentaron un caso legal para exigir reparaciones climáticas—ayuda financiera y responsabilidad de quienes más han contaminado y calentado el planeta. El tribunal falló a su favor, reconociendo el daño sufrido y su derecho a compensación.

**Impacto**
Esta victoria legal es un gran paso hacia la justicia ambiental. Envía un mensaje claro de que los países causantes del daño climático pueden ser responsables. También da esperanza a las comunidades vulnerables, mostrando que sus luchas se escuchan a nivel mundial.

**Próximo paso**
Con esta decisión, estas naciones insulares pueden ahora exigir compensación real y acciones climáticas más fuertes a los grandes contaminadores. El fallo también sirve de precedente para que otras comunidades vulnerables busquen justicia y apoyo.

**Resumen en una frase**
El tribunal más alto del mundo ha empoderado a las islas del Pacífico para luchar por reparaciones climáticas, marcando un giro esperanzador hacia la responsabilidad y la justicia en la crisis climática.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a group of stylized Pacific islander canoes floating peacefully on calm ocean waters beneath a large, balanced scale shaped from natural materials, symbolizing justice, with gentle waves rising to touch small, resilient island silhouettes, all rendered in soft, earthy tones and simple colors.
